of cells is formed around the large circumambient segment of the
'nucleus' (see §17 <s>)</s> also Plate I Fig 5, and Plate II, Fig 2) is presented
by those forms in which this circumambient mass only gives origin
to new cells at its extremity; these in their turn bud-forth others,
which extend and multiply themselves laterally, as well as in
advance; and thus a kind of spiral is produced, which opens out
very rapidly, the lateral portions of its mouth <s>tendering</s> tending to
grow round and embrace the nucleus. _ Thus, starting from the central globular mass; 1, of Fig 8 Plate XI, <s>we</s>
we see that the circumambient mass 2,2, which nearly surrounds
it, gives origin at one of the extremities to a smaller mass 3, from
which bud-off two cells 4.4, which again give origin to four cells
constituting the row 5.5.  The cells of the next row, 6.6, are more
numerous, but are themselves exceeded by those of the zone 7.7, which
not only surrounds it, but extends further backwards upon the
nucleus.  So the cells of the Zones 8.8, 9.9, 10.10, 11.11, and  12.12, progressively
increase in numbers, and each zone extends itself further back upon
the nucleus; until those of the last of these zones nearly meet upon
its yet unenclosed margin. The cells of zone 13.13 do actually meet
